- ## Adaptive
#Adaptive #Monitoring #Challenges #Requirements #Monitoring 
Talwar et al. [10] developed a policy-driven monitoring manager that analyzes events and, using an event-condition- action engine, identifies and enacts changes throughout the monitoring infrastructure

- ## Adaptive
#Adaptive #Monitoring #Challenges #Requirements #Monitoring 
Munawar et al. [9] introduced an adaptive monitoring approach for enterprise systems where developers first identify sets of low-collection-cost metrics to serve as basic health indicators.

- ## Adaptive
#Adaptive #Monitoring #Challenges #Requirements #Monitoring 
foresight of anticipating potential events and corrective actions at design time [10].

- ## Adaptive
#Adaptive #Monitoring #Challenges #Requirements #Monitoring 
collecting correlated pairs of metrics iden- tified at design time may fail to detect anomalies in other non-correlated metrics [9]

- ## Adaptive
#Adaptive #Monitoring #Challenges #Requirements #Monitoring 
Mylopoulos et al. [5] developed a framework for monitoring software requirements that adaptively tunes the granularity of log data gathering and processing by transforming it into a compact propositional encoding that can be ana- lyzed by satisfiability solvers. These adaptive monitoring approaches [4], [5], [24] focus on minimizing the amount of data that must be processed and distributed to diagnose a system’s behavior

- ## Objective
#Objective #Requirements #Monitoring 
A key objective of requirements monitoring is to gather information from an executing system to assess whether it satisfies its requirements

- ## Objective
#Objective #Requirements #Monitoring 
Research on requirements monitoring has largely focused on designing reusable frameworks for monitoring require- ments [2], [6]–[8] and approaches for diagnosing condi- tions conducive to a requirement violation [5]

- ## Objective
#Objective #Requirements #Monitoring 
The primary objectives of requirements monitoring are to detect conditions conducive to a requirements violation [2], and to determine whether requirements are satisfied at run time [6], [7]

- ## Definitions
#Definitions #Requirements #Monitoring 
Requirements Monitoring. Requirements monitoring is a specific instance of monitoring that determines the degree to which a system satisfies its requirements during execu- tion [6].

- ## Definitions
#Definitions #Requirements #Monitoring 
Internal monitoring refers to the gathering and measuring of information on how the system itself is performing. External monitoring, on the other hand, refers to the gathering and measuring of how the execution environ- ment that surrounds the system itself is behaving

- ## Definitions
#Definitions #Requirements #Monitoring 
![](data:image/png;base64,)

- ## Monitors
#Monitors #Measuring #Methods #Requirements #Monitoring 
Software monitors, at Level 1 in Figure 1, can be config- ured to report data in active or passive modes [24]. Active monitors only report, or push, values when an interesting event occurs. In contrast, passive monitors probe, or poll, system components and sensors at a specific time frequency and report gathered data regardless of whether an interesting event occurred or not.

- ## Frameworks
#Frameworks #Requirements #Monitoring 
Fickas and Feather [6], [7], and subsequently Robinson [2], [21], developed frameworks for monitoring the satisfaction of requirements at runtime. In general, to apply these ap- proaches, developers model requirements through a goal- based modeling language (such as KAOS [22]), identify assumptions that could be violated at run time and translate them into event conditions

- ## AGAP
#AGAP #Frameworks #Requirements #Monitoring 
Prieto et al. [4] proposed A-GAP, an approach that dynamically configures filters to control the distribution of monitoring updates over a set of management nodes, thus achieving a given monitoring accuracy while minimizing the maximum processing load at management nodes

- ## COMPAS
#COMPAS #Frameworks #Requirements #Monitoring 
Mos et al. [24] introduced Compas, an approach for automatically switching monitors between active and passive modes

- ## RELAX
#RELAX #Frameworks #Requirements #Monitoring 
RELAX [25] requirements language and process may be leveraged to address uncertainty into the monitoring analysis.

- ## PlatoRE
#PlatoRE #Frameworks #Requirements #Monitoring 
Self-reconfiguration enables a dynamically adaptive sys- tem (DAS) to continuously satisfy its requirements even as system and environmental conditions change [1]. To verify that a DAS satisfies its requirements at run time, it must monitor itself and its execution environment by continuously probing components and sensors to obtain data.

- ## PlatoRE
#PlatoRE #Frameworks #Requirements #Monitoring 
Plato-RE, an evolutionary computation-based approach that combines the concepts of requirements monitoring and adaptive sampling to enable a DAS to detect possible requirements violations while minimizing monitoring costs

- ## PlatoRE
#PlatoRE #Frameworks #Requirements #Monitoring 
Plato-RE leverages and extends Plato [17], a genetic algorithm-based approach for decision-making in autonomic systems [18].

- ## PlatoRE
#PlatoRE #Frameworks #Requirements #Monitoring 
First, Plato-RE periodically uses a set of utility functions to assess how well requirements are being satisfied, and thus detect conditions conducive to a requirement violation

- ## PlatoRE
#PlatoRE #Frameworks #Requirements #Monitoring 
Genetic Algorithms. A genetic algorithm [19] is a stochastic search-based technique often used to efficiently generate optimal or near-optimal solutions to combinatorial optimization problems in vast and complex solution spaces.

- ## Assessing
#Assessing #Requirements #Satisfaction #Challenges #Requirements #Engineering 
Several approaches have been proposed to detect such conditions. For instance, developers may analyze requirements and their assumptions to anticipate conditions that may cause those assumptions to fail [7].
